Community News For April

30 Apr 2002

\nAnother month gone, another stack of accomplishments by the evolt.org community. As a reminder, this is open to anyone in the community, so if you missed a chance to toot your horn, add a comment, and watch for the announcement for next month's news.\n

evolt.org

\nThree interesting tidbits this month about the community you love to parse.\n

\nSpeaking of browsers.evolt.org (keep up already), a big thanks out to Harley Jacoubsen for providing archives of Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.01 through 6.0 for win32, including some service packs. Some of you may recall that we've been trying to get fully-functioning, self-contained versions of those browsers forever. Now we've got 'em. They went up this past weekend, adding some 518MB to the overall browser archive, which now weighs in at just over three solar masses.\n

\nThe final touches have been put on the evolt.org case study to be featured in a book by glasshaus slated for May release titled Usability: The Site Speaks for Itself. Pre-order your copy today and see funny pictures of the authors who wrote about sites like evolt.org, MetaFilter, Google, and others.\n

\nLou Rosenfeld and \nPeter Morville are \nalso in the final touches of the second \nedition for their O'Reilly \nbook on Information Architecture. In this second edition they are including \na case study of evolt.org where Lou presents a very novel and eye opening approach \nto the Information Architecture of our beloved community. Marlene \nand mantruc had the \nchance to read the chapter and give some feedback, and they can tell us that it \ntalks very well of us, so be prepared for a huge troop of new members once it \nhits the bookstores.\n

Evoltspottings

\n

All over the web, people are looking to see what evolters have to say, and sometimes they point their users back to the source. Here are some of the pointers, all noticed this month

\n
    \n
  • Zeldman.com pointed readers over to Aardvark's End of the free content ride? article
    • \n
  • MartinB's article on Zope blogging got spotted and referenced by compulsive blog evangelist Dave Winer
    • \n
  • Brian King's architect's client metaphor got reposted on Flashkit\n
    • \n
  • TalkGraphics described thelist as having many cold fusion people on and are all extremely helpful.
    • \n
\n

Thanks to the many people who have taken the time to cite evolt.org in their own work

Evolt's direction

\n

\nAs a reminder to all members, feel free to take part in the future (and even current) direction of evolt.org over at theforum. As I write this, there's lots of good discussion going on, and your voices need to be heard.\n

Duette evolticon in Santiago

Last week, djc visited \n javier in Santiago \n de Chile. It was very shocking (and relieving) for mantruc to get to meet \n an evolt.org member in the flesh, and finally have evidence that they (you) \n all DO exist in real life, outside of his head and monitor. Dan and Jenny were \n there for a week -which is a very short time to visit such a varied country- \n but the hosts Pilar and javier managed to have them visit as many places as \n possible is such a short timeframe, and have them enjoy (in true evolt gluttony \n stlye) of the local food and wine goods (mainly centered towards seafood, given \n the visitors' veggie habits) of their country. At arrival they were so exhausted \n from the 17-hour flight that they slept over a mild-to-considerable earthquake.

\n

After Dan and Jenny toured around the neurotic capital \n of the country, where Dan wasn't able to perform his famous traffic-stopping \n act (they hardly stop at pedestrian crosses), the four adventurers joined for \n a crazy weekend passing to the winery of Concha \n y Toro and it's famous Cellar of the Devil (Casillero del Diablo), a flash \n tour along the central coast, sleeping at the "historical" location \n of Algarrobo (where mantruc was when the evolt.org name and logo came to life), \n and the famous port of Valparaiso, \n where they visited the museum \n at the house of the Nobel \n winning poet Neruda, \n with all his lovely sense of play.

\n

Then the "crazy gringos" headed towards the ever-lovely southern \n town of Pucon \n and enjoyed some hot springs, and yet more food. On their way back they were \n surveyed for the national \n census, which takes place every 10 years, and then headed back home to Wisconsin, \n wow what a ride!

Our members

Paul Cowan

Australian evolter Paul Cowan is the very proud Dad of a shiny new baby\ngirl, the extremely gorgeous Alice Kallista Gemmell Cowan, born on the 7th of March. As only a true evolter could arrange, Paul had built Alice her own website within a week of the birth...

Ben Phillips

\nInchima have this week secured a contract for the OCS foundation, which is the alumni for all graduates of the US forces training schools. Ben's organization will be supplying them with community tools and consulting.\n

Dave McLean

\nOne of our founding members, Dave has landed himself some new work in the Calgary advertising scene. Working for Creative Intelligence Agency (yes, that's CIA) Dave will be responsible for not only developing the company's Web presence, but also developing sites for the agency's clients. Dave will also be involved in advertising design and strategy for CIA's numerous clients.\n

Hugh Blair

\nHugh (hblair) has recently been elected Chair of the Individual Domain\nName Owner's Constituency (IDNO: http://www.idno.org). Hugh's involvement\nwith this organization and over a decade of experience in Internet domain\nname and web policies contributed to his nomination and election. His\noutlook on the Internet experience is to involve others in the web policy\nprocess. To this end, he encourages anyone interested to become involved\nin the process at IDNO.\n

Adrian Roselli (aardvark)

\nAdrian has won an award in his local chapter of the American Advertising Federation for the design of his company site, Algonquin Studios. The award may be a gold or silver, but he won't know until he accepts it in early May. His company also won a design award in the same event for the site for photographer Rhea Anna.\n

Shirley Kaiser

\nIf you're interested in Shirley Kaiser's forthcoming album (not called "Warmly," although that is how Joel says it's performed) Joel Canfield (spinhead) has scribbled a few notes on his musiblog.\n

Javier Velasco (mantruc)

\n

mantruc changed his job in an upshift move which was amazingly lucky: the week \n after he left, his former employer \n announced the shut down of its office in Santiago (phew!). His new job is as \n Information Architect - Web Designer for a big \n news company. They are working on a very interesting project but he can't \n disclose more because it's secret.

Joshua Olson

\n

On April 30, Joshua became a father (for the first time) of a baby girl. 7lb 4oz (3.289 kg). Her name is Jenna Marie. Congratulations from all your friends at evolt.org, Joshua.

Brent Leideritz

\n

Web designer and photographer, Brent Leideritz, an evolter from Adelaide, South Australia, invites everyone to his photographic exhibition to be opened on May 17 2002. The online invitation for the exhibition can be found at the same site where an online gallery can be browsed after the exhibition.

Submissions

\n

The evolt.org Monthly Recap is a summary of awards, meetings, and fresh opportunities relevant to all of us. Submitted items from month to month may be of varying relevance to others depending on the number of opportunities. The important thing, though, is that you can share more about yourself, and learn more about the people that make up the evolt.org Monthly Recap introductory article.

\n

If you're proud of it, send it in. Don't be shy.

\n

Please send all submissions via the contact form. Any queries or clarifications can be sent via the same method.
